description:
A complete web based school management system built on .NET, C# and MSSQL for INDIANSERVERS; This was a freelance project that I did for indianservers.

There are many features in this web campus, the beautiful User Interface gives you a new experience, as the application is full of AJAX the page won’t be refreshed for each and every POST or GET request. Which make the site faster.

The site has the following features for Administration i.e, admin login,

  • Primary Data Setup (Courses, Sections, Medium, Languages, Departments, Nationality, Category, Religions, Mother Tongue , Seat type etc..
  • Subjects Setup (Adding the different subject in a particular course, including the subject pass marks, number of credits, faculty, Syllabus etc..
  • Communication Zone (A personal messaging stuff and Announcements, admin can send messages to any of the user in the application)
  • Students Zone -
    • Adding New Students, Bulk upload student from a .CSV file
    • Managing the student details.
    • Adding new student automatically creates a new parent with same password.
  • Faculty Zone -
    • Adding Faculty,
    • Managing the faculty,
    • Assigning the subjects to the faculty
  • Exams Zone -
    • Setup a Exam for course.
    • Updating the marks for a exam, (by each student, by each course)
    • Reports and Analysis
  • Attendance Zone-
    • Setup the working day and working hours of a particular course
    • Take the attendance(mark absents)
    • Attendance can be taken two ways, by each student or by each course/class
    • Attendance Reports.
  • Fee Zone -
    • Setup the fee type.
    • Accept the payment from the students or parents
    • Generate the due details and reports

Then next the Faculty login..

  • Faculty login, Front page has a sliding boxes which contains the latest Announcements, Messages, Subjects of his own etc..
  • He can update the syllabus of the subjects, prescribed books etc..
  • Updates the student marks and attendance.
  • And also have the Internal Communication, Can send message to all the students and parents.

Students Login..

  • Front page has sliding boxes which contains the Announcements, New Messages, Subjects list and the brief attendance Report.
  • Fee Zone - Fee payment history and the due details
  • Marks Zone - Can view the marks and percentages in a particular exam and also see the Class toppers in that particular exam.
  • Attendance Zone - View the attendance percentage by month, and detiled view of his attendance
  • Profile Zone - He can view that full profile of his own
  • Finally the Internal Communication, Can Send a personal message to the faculty or Administrator.

Parents Login..

Parent login have the same features as that the students has...
title: School Management System

description:
Site developed for Crux Metals and Minerals, it took 3 or 4 days to complete the design i think. It was developed in asp.net visual studio, with base HTML5 Boilerplate default template.

Using the Visual Studio 2010 Express, we can develop the site with a rapid speed. Concept of the Master Pages done all the work. So we just need to fill the content in the pages. Any correction in the common content like menu bar or logo we need not change the data in each and every page, just a simple change in the master page will affect all the change in all the pages.

Nivo Slider - Nivo Slider is a Jquery image slider with give a flash like effects in the transitions. It’s my favourite slider, Used it with some images in all the pages.

Enquiry - In the enquiry page we have a small enquiry form which directly send a mail to the customer email address. The Visual Studio inbuilt form validation make my work easy, without going for any 3rd party Jquery or Javascript Validation Engines. Just a drag and drop, done!!!

HTML5 Boilerplate -In lot of my project i will use this base template, it is difficult to start everything from the scratch, HTML5 Boilerplate will provide all the css, js and png fixes which are very common in all the projects.
title: cruxmm.com

description:
Low cost vehicle tracking system to help truck owners in small towns.
Date
Jul 2011 to Aug 2011
Role
Researcher
Developer
Tasks
Visual Design
Development
Tools
jQuery
HTML
CSS
Photoshop
Summary

I developed a low cost vehicle tracking mechanism using Google Maps and GPS device on the truck. This is application is developed in order to help the small Truck owners who cannot effort a costly tracking systems.

Project Links
  1. Application Link
How this works ?

A GPS tracking device must be attached to the vehicle and an SIM card of any network with GPS enabled. This device pings the nearest tower with the exact Latitude and Longitude along with the IMEA number of the device number, tower will send it to the server connected with internet next the server stores and maps the data with already store IMEA recored. Later that client can login to their account and monitor all the vehicles that are registered. Below is a diagram showing how this vehicle tracking works.

Hardware

In the present market there are plethora of options to find out a low cost GPS's tracking device (It costs around ₹1500 to ₹2000 in year 2011). We can get any of the device that have a GSM option and able to ping server. Here is an image of how a tracking device looks like. One have to setup other hardware to enable options to alert on low fuel, low battery etc...

The main idea of the project is to track the vehicle using the GPS device attached to the moving object. We need to place a GPS Hardware device in the vehicle that we are going to track, each GPS device has it machine number and it will communicate the server socket using a GPS protocol which is given by the hardware device.

Initial Prototypes

As the idea of tracking clear. I started working on the initial prototypes, marking all the features that present in the application. Some initial thoughts here..

Features available
  • Customer Can Register any Number of vehicles into their account.
  • Each vehicle must have a unique number.
  • Live tracking (locates the position of the vehicle at present)
  • Gives the Status like stopped, moving and also the Speed at which it is going on.
  • Different types of alerts like Over Speed, Fuel Low, Battery Low etc..
  • Route history of the vehicle(the route at which the vehicle has crossed in the given time)
  • Other features like Fleet Usage, Sensor, Trip, Vehicle distance etc..
ScreenShots
title: Track my Truck

description:
A web application for Training and Placement Cell to maintaining and generate different reports of student data. This was built on asp .NET using Telrik components.

Code on github: https://github.com/websiddu/tandp

Started with listing out different stakeholders involved in the application and their role and actions. Narrowed down to three different roles.

  • Student
  • TPO (Placement officer)
  • Dept Coordinator

List of the high level tasks that these different roles can perform on the application. The Placement officer can perform these actions.

Administrator or TPO - Admin or TPO can manage all the students, Department coordinators and Placements. Generate different type of reports based on the given input and also can generate some advanced reports. Some of the tasks are listed below.

  • Manage Announcements
  • Manage Students
    • Create, edit or delete any student in the system
    • Reset student password
  • Update Placement Info
  • Reports
    • Get general filtered reports
    • Get advanced multi level reports
  • Manage Coordinators
    • Add, edit or remove department coordinators
    • Reset coordinators password
  • Setup Primary Data
    • Manage(CRUD operations) departments
    • Configure the application
  • Change Password

Student - Student can log in to the system and update his/her profile, academic records and placement information.

  • Manage profile
    • Edit his/her details
    • Update profile picture
  • Manage Academic details
    • Update the semester make and backlogs
    • Request the Dept Coordinator to Approve
    • Update his resume
  • Messaging
    • Send message to TPO, coordinator or any other student
    • Receive announcements
  • Placement details
    • Dream company
    • Update placed in companies

Department Coordinator- Dept Coordinator can approve student request then student will be will be listed in the eligible list.

Later, I created story board with some kind of visuals that looks like below.

Moving forward, I created paper prototype for each and every screen. You can see one of it below.

* Not posting all the wireframes due to space constraint.

Finally, these are some screen-shots of the application..

description:
A simple 3cups games developed in HTML, CSS and jQuery.
Date
September 2011
Tasks
Development
JavaScript
CSS
HTML
jQuery
Summary
This is a simple game implemented in jquery. When i am designing this site i thought of designing some game in jquery so started working on it with in one day i have completed the whole game.
Project Links
  1. Link to the application
  2. Link to the sourcecode
Logic

I used 3 images for the boxes, the open box contains 2 parts top and bottom, next the closed box. I have used 2 images for kick 2 image for kick, one i the jumping image and next one is the smiling image.

Using the css Z-index i mate that effect that character is into the box and hiding in the box. And the logic is very simple. I have taken a random number first which is the answer, and placed the kick in it then next an array of [1,2,3] and for every 500ms i have called the shuffle function

shuffle = function(o){
    for(var j, x, i = o.length; i; j = parseInt(Math.random() * i), x = o[--i], o[i] = o[j], o[j] = x);
    return o;
  };
Screenshots
title: 3Cups Game in Jquery

description:
A data visualization project, visualizing the road accidents in India.
Date
Nov 2014
Tasks
Design
Development
Tools & Technologies
JavaScript
CSS
HTML
Google Maps
D3.js
Summary

India has one of the largest road network in the world. However, Road safety is an issue of national concern. Surge in population and motorization in the country along with expansion of road network contributes to the number of road accidents, injuries and fatalities.

I tried to visualize various dimensions and magnitude of road accidents in India. This visualization will help to create awareness and assist in decision making in the area of road safety. I hope, this interactive visualization would be useful for policy makers, citizens, and civil society organizations working In areas that have an influence on road safety.

description:
Visualizing trends makes, and the usage of Alternative Fuel Vehicles in the US.
Date
Nov 2014 – Dec 2014
Platform
Web
Role
UX Designer & Developer
My Tasks
Wireframing
Prototyping
Development
Tools
D3.js
JavaScript
GitHub
QGIS
Adobe Photoshop
Collaborators
Ivan Koveshnikov
Laurel Stone
Sangeun Lee
Summary

I worked on a small team to build a D3 data visualizations to allow users to explore differen alternative fuel vehicles. We followed a user-centered design process in which we interviewed and tested our designs with users. Ultimately, we created a D3 dashboard in which users play with it. The Viz was built using data visualization best practices (such as using proper visual encoding methods and supporting ideal data interactions) learned in a graduate information visualization course at UW (511A).

Project Links
  1. Link to the visualizations
  2. Final paper/documentation (PDF, 4 MB)
  3. Final presentation/documentation (PDF, 4 MB)
Introduction

HCDE 511A presented an opportunity for Team Tesseract to produce a complex interactive visualization. Focusing on trends, makes, and the usage of Alternative Fuel Vehicles in the US, we utilized the UCD process to create an underlying outline, proposal, and preliminary prototype with Tableau, all whilst incorporating best practices for visualization features. Conducting a user research survey, connecting our goals towards consumer needs, and desiring to have a highly interactive element focused our efforts on creating a multi-tab visualization crafted with D3. This paper will lay out-out our design process, challenges, connectivity to the class, and discuss our final visualization which can be found here (http://afvs.me)

User Research

In the early prototyping phase, we sent out a survey to understand more about what types of information would be the most useful to our users, their understanding of the prototyped visual formats we had already created, and any missing information they might expect to see. An overarching goal of this early research was to validate our design goals, the value of the data, and to identify if our visualization concepts were usable.

Design Process
Persona
Ideation

Based on the data we have we generated different possible interesting charts that we can use to communicate the data to the users. Here are some of the initial prototypes that we designed for our application.

Usability Testing

Here are some of the findings from our usability testing

  1. Tabbed interface worked
  2. The intro and guided tour helped the users to understand the viz better.
  3. Surprised by the abundant amount of information.

Issues

  1. Participants weren’t sure how AFV’s compared against total car numbers within states.
  2. Several participants expected to see regular gasoline information.
  3. Participants wanted to compare graphs on the overview page.
Final product
title: Alternative Fuel Vehicles in US

description:
How we can encourage high school students to volunteer for community service projects?
Focus
Date
November 2014 – December 2014
Platform
Web
Tasks
User research
Sketching
Wireframing
Prototyping
User testing
Hify Prototyping
Documentation
Tools
HTML
CSS
Adobe Photoshop
Adobe Illustrator
Collaborators
Amani Ahmed Dye
David Harris
Summary

With a small team in UW's HCDE 518, I conducted user research; created wireframes, visual designs, a prototype, and detailed specifications; and performed basic user testing for a web application to encourage high school students to participate in community projects.

Project Links
  1. Link to the prototype
  2. Final paper/documentation (PDF, 7 MB)
  3. Final presentation/documentation (PDF, 14 MB)
Introduction

High school students are older children who are, traditionally in America, 15 to 18 years old. We define volunteering to be any activity, which involves spending time, unpaid, doing something which aims to benefit the environment, an individual, or a group, other than yourself. We also scope community service projects (referred to as projects for the rest of this document) to be activities organized by students, teachers, local businesses/organizations, which were intended to improve the local community in some fashion.

Process

We followed proper UCD process to solve this design problem. We first started with user research followed by ideation, Low-fi prototypes, Hi-fi prototypes and at test our ideas each and every state.

User Research

As we have the limited time and also we are working with school students. We were asked to choose only 3 user research methods for this project from the 51 different methods in the IDEO cards. So, we choose Surveys, Still Photo Survey, and Affinity Diagram as our research methods.

1. Survey

The first method we used was “Surveys and Questionnaire". This method uses a list of questions focused on pulling out certain characteristics of users. The users for this method were students and teachers. Since we are working with minors, we had their parents sign a consent form in order to participate. One of our big constraints was time, so this method allowed us to get data from a number of people all at once. We were able to send a survey to students via Facebook and in person using an on-line form, and we also sent a questionnaire to teachers via email. We received 12 responses to the survey. This method also allowed us to target our learning by asking specific questions related to how students are currently using their time to volunteer and how teachers are finding projects. [Survey Questions] (http://bit.ly/1yFS472)

Results
  • Most students said they spend 8-10 hours or more per week doing school work
  • Most students said they spend (or would spend) 2-4 hours per month volunteering
  • Most students said they have more time to volunteer during the weekend
  • Most students we surveyed are part of a school group or club like ASB (student government).
  • Most students said they keep in touch with school clubs and organizations through text, and also meeting in person and email.
  • Most students volunteer in order to help their community.
2. Still Photo Survey

This second method we used was the "Still Photo Survey" method. It is used to reveal patterns of behavior that have to do with a certain product or context. It works by following a script of what type of photos to take and shooting those pictures while in the environment of users and stakeholders. We wanted to capture photos of students submitting a project, working on a project, and organizing people.

3. Affinity Diagram

The last method we used was the "Affinity Diagram," which groups particular design elements together based on their relationship to each other - similarities, location, interactions, etc. The users for this method were students and teachers. We thought this would be a great method to compliment the other methods we used. It would allow us to synthesize all of our findings from the surveys and photos by grouping our insights from the data. We were able to write down on post it notes elements of our design based on the data points we gained from users.

Persona

Detailed persona can be found in this following document.

Ideation & Low-fi prototypes
Hi-fi Prototype

The high fidelity wire frames can be found here http://websiddu.github.io/building-blocks/#/.

To create a high fidelity prototype we used HTML, CSS and JavaScript. We chose HTML and CSS, because of our familiarity with this technology and flexibility it provided to quickly iterate between versions. We also used “Angular.js” front-end framework for creating different templates and Git/Github for version control. Github allowed us to track and compare our design decisions each at every stage.

Usability Testing

For our usability study, we used the think aloud technique along with a survey. The study included five participants total - two teachers and three high school students from TAF Academy in Kent, WA.

We performed the test on the Google Chrome browser with a laptop computer. There was also a camera setup behind the participants, in order to capture their thinking aloud and any critical incidents.

Report

We wrote a design spec document at the end of the quarter and also presented to the class. You can find the presentation and design spec document here.

  1. Final paper/documentation (PDF, 7 MB)
  2. Final presentation/documentation (PDF, 14 MB)
Future work

In the future, we’d be interested in running the usability test again with the new design improvements. The test would include more than five participants - five teachers and five students. Ultimately, we’d like for the participants to come from different schools. While TAF Academy was a convenient place to do the usability study, it provided a limited perspective since most students there are already active in community projects. Identifying a few teachers at multiple High Schools who could give us access to their students would be a good route to achieving this goal.

Another feature that we’d like to integrate into the site is an internal messaging system. This would allow users of a project to communicate with their team about the work they are doing. an internal system decreases the need to exchange email addresses when sharing information between team members. Although, there will be a setting to notify users via email when they receive a new internal system message.

We’d also like for at least one of the teachers to run a pilot at their school. The pilot could include one class or multiple classes over a period of at least one semester. This would give us enough data to glean additional insights about the current design. Before running a pilot, the site would also need to finish being developed. This could actually be an opportunity for a High School student to get some experience in user centered design and software development. This project is a gift that keeps on giving.
title: Building Blocks

Project Links
  1. Demo of the portal
  2. Source Code

Green Certification Programs at the University of Washington are recognition programs intended to reduce the environmental impact of various spaces across campus by educating students, faculty, and staff about sustainable practices. The programs provide an evaluation framework with resources to implement the practices within their spaces, in alignment with strategies laid out in the UW Climate Action Plan.

Process

Though this project has less budget, throughout the project I followed the User Centered Design process. This includes lot of ideation, paper prototyping, usability testing followed by developing the product.
